newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs end at 4-mo high as Aso clarifies rate remark.
newsitem.headline: JGBs end at 4-mo high as Aso clarifies rate remark.

text.p: The key September 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) futures contract closed at a four-month high on Tuesday, retaining firmness from the morning.
"The market was looking for somebody who would give it a push from behind, but there was no such person in the afternoon," said a dealer at a "Big Four" brokerage house.

JGBs were boosted by panic buying towards midday partly due to comments by Economic Planning Agency Minister Taro Aso, who said a report from the United States earlier this month that had him saying it was possible Japan's official discount rate would be raised by the year-end was not entirely correct.
Aso told a news conference the interviewer did not refer to a time frame in his question and he only said it was possible the Bank of Japan (BOJ) would raise rates.
The September closed at 127.12, the highest close since April 10. Monday's finish was 126.95.

"Aso's denial fit the view, now becoming dominant in the market, that there will be no rate rise by the year-end," said a dealer at an agricultural financial institution. The remarks triggered buying at the long end of the JGB yield curve, sending the key 182nd 10-year JGB yield to a new low.

"But compared with today's rally in JGB futures, the gains in the cash benchmark were limited. That suggested operators are still very cautious about buying at the current high levels," the dealer said.
The yield of key 182nd issue stood at 2.065 percent at 0649 GMT after falling to an all-time low for any benchmark JGB of 2.060 percent in early afternoon.
The yield closed at 2.085 percent on Monday.
There was also some talk in the morning that the BOJ's next "tankan" quarterly survey of business sentiment would be poor and that its release might be delayed as a result.
But traders said many considered the talk confusing because the September tankan has been scheduled for release in early October since January of this year.
Asked about the talk, a BOJ spokesman told Reuters that he had no comment to make on the market rumours.
The market has been waiting for institutional investors to return to the market after summer holidays, as their moves are seen as essential to help bonds find direction.
But traders said no significant investor activity was detected, except for option-related JGB trading and buying of the 197th 10-year issue, probably by public funds.
Elsewhere, bank debentures firmed as they caught up with the recent rally in JGBs, traders said.

Few traders felt a try for the all-time high for any key JGB futures contract of 127.34 was likely this week amid a continuing shortage of fresh factors and ahead of a 10-year JGB auction expected early next week.

"If the September rises to 127.40-127.50, the Finance Ministry would set a new coupon rate at 2.2 percent, much lower than the record low of 2.4 percent. I don't think that is likely to happen," said the first dealer. -- Risa MAEDA Tokyo Treasury Desk (813) 3432-8570 email: tokyo.newsroom@reuters.com
